awd_titl_txt: HCC: Small: Copyright and Online Communities: An Empirical Study of Social Norms and User Conceptions
awd_abstract_narration:
This research will develop a detailed understanding of interactions between copyright law, social norms, and user behavior in online communities where people create and share content.  Recent work has found that the following five things are typically different: (1) what the law says; (2) what people think the law says; (3) what people think is ethical; (4) community norms; and (5) what people actually do. How can we better understand users, how they engage with copyrighted content online, and how they interact with one another in environments of creative sharing? To fully answer these questions, it is necessary to address all five dimensions, and their complex interactions. This research takes up the task of understanding how these dimensions function within different online communities, how community norms evolve, and what lessons can be derived for online community management and design.

The Internet is a rich medium for a vast spectrum of creative activity. People make original art, write stories, make videos, and share them with others online. The raw material for this wealth of creativity is a combination of original ideas and existing content, including the remix of copyrighted material created by corporations or other Internet users. As a result, while the nuances of copyright law were once something that largely mattered only to commercial producers of content, technology has changed all of this. With both copying and wide dissemination made orders of magnitude easier thanks to digital content and the Internet, copyright is now something that touches the average computer user on almost a daily basis. This is particularly true for the large number of online amateur content creators. However, just because the law is more relevant to more people does not mean it is more easily understandable.

The same confusions that have always existed in applications of the law have been exacerbated by technological advances. Social norms that form within these communities of creators do not necessarily track exactly to the law, but represent shared understandings and constructions, as well as ethical intuitions. These norms interact in intricate ways with other sources of order in online communities - legal rules, site policies, and technology-imposed control - and only together provide a complete picture of user behavior.

This study will gather data from three sources: (1) current online community policies; (2) public conversations about intellectual property occurring on current online sites and archives from older communities; and (3) interviews with creators of online creative content. The analysis will focus on teasing out the norms that exist within different communities, how they have evolved, and how they interact with the law as written and as enacted by community policies.

The results of this research will better inform online community design, and more broadly contribute to our fundamental understanding of how social norms operate in complex sociotechnical systems.  It will provide evidence-based guidance for online community designers, and for policy makers tasked with helping the law adapt effectively to new technologies.  Broader educational impacts of this research include the training of two graduate students in this interdisciplinary field of study. Additionally, this research will enrich the curriculum for the required undergraduate class CS 4001 "Computers, Society, and Professionalism."

por.por_cntn:
While copyright law was once only the domain of lawyers and professional content producers, now it can be relevant to anyone with an Internet connection and a “share” button. However, just because more people are engaging with copyright doesn’t mean that these complex laws are any easier to understand—particularly when it comes to gray areas such as content re-use. Fair use, the part of U.S. copyright law that creates exceptions to copyright protection for things like remix and critique, has always been decided on a case-by-case basis, creating ambiguity even in existing case law. Particularly when technological advances have only exacerbated confusions in the law, how can everyday amateur content creators be expected to understand and apply fair use when even lawyers and judges argue over its application?

Though copyright law online has been written about extensively by legal scholars, empirical work connecting computing and law is rare. In order to better understand the landscape of copyright and user-generated content (with an eye towards both policymaking and online platform design), we explored how copyright law impacts online content creators and how people without legal expertise make decisions about what they can and cannot do when it comes to content re-use. Over the lifetime of this project, we conducted over 50 in-depth interviews with online content creators, surveyed over 400 users of social media and user-generated content platforms, and completed qualitative content analyses of hundreds of public conversations about copyright from 8 different user-generated content platforms. Taken together, this research provided a wealth of information about the knowledge, attitudes, and norms among online content creators—from the law as written to copyright clauses in Terms of Service to the complex community norms that can form around content re-use.

Much of what we uncovered had to do with chilling effects caused largely by misunderstandings of copyright law. We found that many people choose not to create or share certain types of creative work or not to use certain online platforms for fear of getting into legal trouble. We determined that much of this fear is due to an information problem—a spread of misinformation, conflicting information and rules from different sources, and difficulty in interpreting or understanding actual legal rules. In short, there is a pervasive usability problem related to law and policy information, and it is impacting the ways that people share creative work and use technology.

Analyzing the copyright licenses on websites where users contribute content, we found that the reading level of those licenses was well above that of the average Internet user, and it would also be unreasonably time consuming for anyone to read the terms of all sites they use. Further, licensing terms vary in unpredictable ways that do not match user expectations. In a survey of people who contribute to those sites, we found that user expectations differ by type of website. Moreover, the most undesirable terms, such as right to modify, appear more frequently than users expect. These findings led to a series of recommendations for online content platforms around how to support information sharing, scaffold copyright knowledge, and create policies that are visible and understandable.

We also found that in the absence of clear rules, social norms can play a larger role in decision-making and behavior around copyright than law or policy. We had a closer look at fan creation communities, which have longstanding social norms around copyright, to examine this phenomenon. In these communities, strong and positive norms around content re-use are self-enforced through social norms. We also examined a fan fiction archive that was designed and developed by community members, as a case study of how these kinds of norms can be built into the design of a platform. As a result, our recommendations for content platforms also include how existing norms of a community can be leveraged to regulate behavior, or how to design for encouraging positive norms around content re-use.

Through the course of this project, we concluded that copyright law is an important component of how content creators interact with online platforms. Therefore, it is important for designers, technologists, and researchers to have an understanding not only of the law itself, but also of how users might incorrectly perceive the law or what user norms around content re-use or copying might be. Our findings and recommendations suggest directions for online platforms to educate users and police copyright decisions, while avoiding potential chilling effects.
